subject: Critical Thinking
title: Correlation vs. Causation: Together Doesn't Mean Because
description: A quick, practical guide to Correlation vs. Causation: Together Doesn't Mean Because.

hook.text: Ice cream sales and drowning deaths both rise in summer. Does ice cream cause drowning? No. Heat causes both.

buildup.text: Correlation: two things happen together. Causation: one thing causes the other. They look identical but aren't.

discovery.text: A hidden third variable (confound) often explains both. Or the causation runs backwards. Or it's pure coincidence.

twist.text: A famous spurious correlation: US spending on science correlates 99.79% with suicides by hanging. Obviously meaningless.

climax.text: To prove causation, you need controlled experiments, temporal precedence, and elimination of alternative explanations.

punchline.text: Together doesn't mean because. Always ask: what else could explain this?

quiz.question: Why doesn't correlation prove causation?
options: A third variable, reverse causation, or coincidence could explain the relationship
